Daniel,

The markets are always changing so I need something that is evolut=
ionary, 
changes as the markets change. So some kind of loop back informati=
on is required 
from the market environment. The issue I have it that forec=
ast would be correct 
for few bars then Neural network would have to be ret=
rained. I have more success 
just optimising data periodically using a GA t=
han neural networks, I believe 
both fused together with some kind of re re=
inforced learning would have benefit.

Thanks I ll have a look to see what =
I can find. 

Peter 




________________________________
From: Daniel Tuoh=
y <danielr2e@...>
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Sun, 7 November, 201=
0 4:19:18
Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Financial trading with Hyperneat

   
Pet=
er,

What you want is a machine learning algorithm.  The many flavors of NE=
AT are 
indeed such algorithms, but NEAT is fairly exotic. My advice is to =
have a go 
with WEKA.  WEKA will provide you with lots of different machine=
 learning 
algorithms (including neural networks), and it should be pretty =
easy for you to 
figure out how to set up an experiment with your data.  It=
 will very well 
documented, and is likely to be easier to use for an ML no=
vice than any NEAT 
distribution, Hyper or otherwise (although I cannot spe=
ak from experience, so I 
am perfectly willing to be corrected on this poin=
t).

Two words of warning:

(1) Make sure you understand what it means to m=
aintain a test set distinct from 
the training data.  Just because you have=
 a model that fits the data well does 
not mean your model has learned anyt=
hing interesting (i.e. anything other than 
noise).  If it predicts well wi=
th an unseen test set, then you've got something.
(2) If you find yourself =
needing advice from the Weka community, you might want 
to keep the nature =
of your data to yourself.  You are likely to receive the same 
reception. 
=

Good luck, and I encourage you to keep an open mind if you should find you=
r 
models unable to predict anything of interest.  And if that should be th=
e case, 
you will at least have had some useful experience with ML and Weka=
 that could 
serve you well with future financial experiments.

Daniel



O=
n Sun, Nov 7, 2010 at 12:00 AM, Peter Henry <blackprinzze@...> wrot=
e:

  
>[Attachment(s) from Peter Henry included below] 
>Hi All, 
>
>This =
debate can go on forever, what proof are you willing to accept?  Planetary =

>cycles affects people moods and in turn affects trade decision in the mar=
kets. 
>
>
>Have a look at this paper its from the Federal Reserve Bank of =
Atlanta, has a 
>brief abstract at the beginning that explains external inf=
luences. 
>
>
>More close to home, is inter-market influences. Correlation =
between markets can  
>also be used to aid prediction in target market. 
>
=
>
>Please don't start a debate on this one!! .. I would like to simply use =
the 
>close prices of the relevant inter-market data to forecast next perio=
d close 
>prices or simply whether there is going to be an up close or down=
 for the next 
>period. 
>
>
>The main reason why I'm interested in this gr=
oup is because the NEAT algorithm  
>provides feedback from current market =
environment  (Correct me if I'm wrong) 
>which in my view is critical.
>
>H=
ope you guys could be of help to point me in the right direction. 
>
>Thank=
s 
>
>Peter 
>
>Millionaires do not use astrology, billionaires do". -J.P. =
Morgan
>
>
>
>
>
>

uidity of the market. I don't think that Uranus's

 and metaphysical. lol

>Peter

      <p>Pete=
r,</p><div><br></div><div>What you want is a machine learning algorithm. &n=
bsp;The many flavors of NEAT are indeed such algorithms, but NEAT is fairly=
 exotic. My advice is to have a go with <a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_blan=
k" href=3D"http://www.cs.waikato.ac.nz/ml/weka/">WEKA</a>.  WEKA will =
provide you with lots of different machine learning algorithms (including n=
eural networks), and it should be pretty easy for you to figure out how to =
set up an experiment with your data.  It will very well documented, an=
d is likely to be easier to use for an ML novice than any NEAT distribution=
, Hyper or otherwise (although I cannot speak from experience, so I am perf=
ectly willing to be corrected on this point).</div>

<div><br></div><div>Tw=
o words of warning:</div><div><br></div><div>(1) Make sure you understand w=
hat it means to maintain a test set distinct from the training data.  =
Just because you have a model that fits the data well does not mean your mo=
del has learned anything interesting (i.e. anything other than noise). &nbs=
p;If it predicts well with an unseen test set, then you've got something.</=
div>

<div>(2) If you find yourself needing advice from the Weka community,=
 you might want to keep the nature of your data to yourself.  You are =
likely to receive the same reception. </div><div><br></div><div>Good l=
uck, and I encourage you to keep an open mind if you should find your model=
s unable to predict anything of interest.  And if that should be the c=
ase, you will at least have had some useful experience with ML and Weka tha=
t could serve you well with future financial experiments.</div>

      <p>H=
i all, <br>
<br>
I don't think this planetary astrological information thin=
g can bring any more benefit than trying just random choices. To be honest,=
 this is so silly I wouldn't try it myself. It's a better idea to observe t=
he Sun's activity than other planets. There are hundreds of thousands of ob=
jects in the solar system, why only planets should have impact on us, as ev=
erything is made from the same stuff? How about exoplanets throughout the g=
alaxy? Astrology is just another twisted kind of stupidity. The market is a=
 chaotic system and the best chances are that it can be predicted for a sho=
rt time. Even this is a hard task, considering the high liquidity of the ma=
rket. I don't think that Uranus's weather has anything to do with the direc=
tion of EUR/USD today, people. This is absolutely silly and metaphysical. l=
ol<br>


<br>
Peter <br>
